comments.commentBody: Bibi is acting like a used car salesman. It seems like he will do anything of say anything when the situation warrants. He goes around the world telling the world not to trust Iran. Now he has shown the world Iran is not the only one to be on guard about. Maybe the relationship with Israel has to change. Maybe the internal politics off Israel should not be so important in America. Maybe once you say you are a racist it very hard to clean it up. Maybe it time the big brother, The U.S., let Israel take a few licks without always running to cover its play. Mr. Netanyahu took off the gloves to win. Now he wants to play by the rules again? Putting him on a short lease is a wise move for Obama. Now he will have to prove he can govern. Mitt ran to the right and couldn.t get back. Didn't they once work together? Seems like they have a similar problem. Europe does not have a parliament that has invited him to speak so I guess he must be worrying about now that maybe he has burned the wrong bridges.He has proven himself to be untrustworthy..

I have the same reaction.  It appears as though people pay attention only to the words and not the actions...in other words, you can build new settlements, kill and imprison and occupy Palestinians right and left, but if you SAY you want peace and a two state solution, people believe you.  Can people really be so naive?

What I think is most amazing about all this, is the number of journalists, and politicians who are acting like this is new information.

Anyone watching the Israeli government for the past few years, possibly decades, who is finding all this news is , at best, hopelessly naive. How many more settlements would you have required? How many thousand more Palestinians civilians would have to be killed before you gave up on Israeli good faith for a two state solution?

So now Bibi actually said the words, talking the talk after a lifetime of walking the walk.

I have to place the reactions somewhere between the "Shock" of Captain Renault in 'Casablanca' and the the many admirers of the Emperor's New Clothes.

If this is a surprise, you haven't been paying attention.

What a huge mistake this ego-driven, self-aggrandizing politician made when he decided to collude with a few Republicans here to embarrass President Obama.
Claiming his speech before the US Congress was "not political" Netanyahu wasted no time in airing tv commercials in Israel showing him speaking and bragging about the "successful result."
Just days before the Israeli voting, Netanyahu reversed his position on a Palestinian independent state, claiming he would no longer support that policy. Enough Jewish voters bought into the lie.
The day after the election, Netanyahu reversed again, saying he never had seriously walked away from a 2-state solution.
This man is a sociopath. He cannot be trusted. President Obama is right to warn Netanyahu that US policy towards Israel will change. US policy must change.
This saga has turned out badly for Israel and could setback US-Israeli relations for decades. At the least, Israel will be more alone than it has been in years.
Netanyahu and Jewish voters made a big mistake.
The conservative media (the fake news) outrage machine is only for Democrats. Just look at the endless Benghazi outrage.

Congress routinely exempts itself from a number of laws the rest of us are required to observe -- we are beginning to form a Soviet style "nomenklatura" class in government & corporations, who are exempted:  remember "Scooter" Libby revealing CIA operatives, and Petraeus handing over classified documents and received a mere slap on the wrist?  And how many Wall Street bankers have been held accountable for their decisions leading to the 2007/2008 meltdown?  They didn't even suffer claw-back of their bonuses.

Why should elected representatives at ANY level be exempt from preserving their records - email or otherwise?

I'm still stunned at the lack of 'outrage' when the Bush administration 'lost' millions of emails for its tenure... and when Mitt Romney left office with his hard drives under his arm (metaphorically speaking) and no trace he'd ever been there.

Congress should pay attention to its own foul nest and quit projecting.

Au contraire,  Lucious wasn't lyin' to Hakeem who asked, "Did she take the money?" Papa's cryptic counter-culture was, "What do you think?" He later gifts his rapper offspring with a private jet and freedom from daddy's interference in his life. EMPIRE strikes gold with its rich tapestry of Shakespearean intrigue and sudsy, nocturnal soap hip-hopera. It is The Lyon in Winter with our presumably moribund King debating which prodigal son to bequeath his corporate realm. The conniving Queen Cookie swirls with Disneyesque devilment as she plans to plop Jamal on the throne and topple her estranged husband. The plots have more twists than a bag of pretzels. Just when loyalties seem solid, they dissolve like a sugar cube in scalding coffee. With the incarcerated cliffhanger of a finale and more unanswered questions than a White House press conference--where's you-know-who's body?--it's certain the sons will never sit on this Empire!

My daughter taught herself to read. She knew the alphabet at two, and started to spell when our neighbor, Bob showed her that his name was a palindrome. At 3, when she finally had the fine-motor skills, she began writing; she never drew. And so by age 4 she realized that she could read words too. She delighted in looking at any printed page to find words she knew. For a while, "the" was her favorite word, since it was virtually everywhere.

A top phonics educator told me flat out that she couldn't have learned to read by spelling, but I saw it happen. We did not teach her at all. As a teacher of K-3 (yes, all at the same time) for years, I guess I should have seen trouble coming. She could read anything, but her comprehension was just not there.I used to pair her with a kid a grade ahead of her who was very bright but could not read a lick (told me he thought it was because he'd been a drug baby, rescued at birth by his grandparents). She would read to him and he'd explain what she'd just read.

Later she was diagnosed as having hyperlexia, which is just what it sounds like, the opposite of dyslexia. She was 13, could read at the graduate-student level, but her comprehension started breaking down about 3rd grade. We later found out about her rare brain anomaly; it's not uncommon for this kind of reading profile to accompany it.
Coach Tommy Amaker makes more than five times what a Harvard professor is paid.
And good for him.
We finally have a President who will stand up to Netanyahu and the right wing Israelis.
OK, at least the US should stop funding the Israeli war machine.
And yet he is the democratically elected leader of Israel. Have US presidents and leaders of other important countries all been honorable men and women?
My personal support for Israel has waned since Mr. N. made the unfortunate decision to speak before the US House.  He is not an honorable man.
More like he doesn't like Mr. N, who apparently just did a 180 on his "I will never" talk to win an election. Obama is the sane one here.

As a teacher of grades K-3 for many years, I can recommend a few more ideas to help early learners, whether or not they are keeping up in school. One of the most powerful was to let kids choose their own books. Visiting the library is a great way to do this, but ownership is even better. My kids had a very small allowance, but they were allowed a bigger "book allowance," usually spent on books from the order forms their teachers sent home monthly. It was exciting to pour over the choices each time, and do the math to get as much as they could. They were not allowed any action figure, movie, or TV books, and there were some other restrictions. Places that sell second-hand books are more common now, and those would also be great shopping venues.

Another important thing is to allow reading that is "below" their leveled books sometimes. This might include letting kids who are supposed to be reading chapter books read picture books instead. (Award-winning and other high-quality picture books often have much richer vocabulary and sentence structure, which is good for kids of all ages.) For beginners and older kids who struggle, rereading is a powerful tool that is not mentioned as often as I think it should be. Sometimes it can be reading aloud in unison, and other times you can alternate reading pages with your child to spice things up. Reading poetry especially lends itself to "choral" readings.

And keep reading to them! Use books above their decoding level.

well, that, and our money, to the tune of 3-4 billion dollars a year, that they love so much.  if they continue to require our money to sustain their nation, then they need to bow to our requests. if not, it is time for israel to stand on their own, period.

It seems like employers ought to take on more apprenticeships of skilled workers in coordination with formal training from local community colleges. They can ensure that work habits and skills are adequate to succeed and provide critical opportunities to practice in real world, real time conditions.

A lot of people can make it through the training classes but can't make it in the workplace for various reasons. An apprenticeship concurrent with the educational experience solves this issue with early identification of problems while they can still be fixed.

I think Netanyahu's reelection is a good thing.

I'm a Republican, but frankly speaking our soft spot for Israel has done a world of harm to our Mideast policy. Maybe it was worth it when they were fighting the underdog fight for survival decades ago, I don't know. Now though, I'd rather US tax dollars not support questionable realpolitik, divide and conquer policies in the middle of a tinderbox of a region. It's too late to undue the reputational effects of fifty years of subsidizing bad faith dealings, but it's never too late to direct our money and attention at other problems going forward.

With a Herzog or a Livni, we could keep up the delusion that Israel is just a run of the mill liberal democracy struggling to get by in a tough neighborhood. With Netanyahu in power, we see what we've really been paying for. I think Israel analogizes very well to Turkey. It's an ally, it's a success story, it's a country with a lot to offer, but we are only fooling ourselves if we think it's the US or Europe in miniature. Majorities of both populations, recent events and elections have shown, embrace leaders and viewpoints that should make us feel uncomfortable.
It's actually very hard to make money on NYC real estate...  Building costs and taxes are very high... Hence the breaks given to spur construction.

Do you know how high the hotel room rate and rental car add-on taxes are in New York? About 25% of the price. NYC already can't attract conventions because of these prohibitive taxes, and you want to charge MORE to tourists?

As for your first point, it was clearly explained in the article: The MTA is one of the few subway systems in the world that is expected to pay for itself.
That's exactly how it works.  Regular users in NYC can take advantage of weekly and monthly discounts that tourists generally don't use.
That's effectively what the monthly card does.

If ridership is increased so much why are prices going up meanwhile infrastructure is not being upgraded, only patched and repaired???

Residents of NYC should be able to pay less for MTA transportation, tourism should pay a higher fee. Done.

NYC city heavily subsidizes upstate and LI infrastructure given the republican state senate. It goes into upstate make-work projects (ever drive route 17- its a fantastic road with little traffic), and prisons.  Cuomo is spending billons on the Tappan Zee. Many voters upstate have this bizarre idea that they are supporting NYC because of "high welfare costs".  Tolling the east river bridges makes much sense- (and I drive across the bridges often). It would be great to see them set the tolls to the equal the cost of a subway fare.  Finally- the proposed train to LGA- you gotta be kidding me. It would take forever to get there. There are many better things to spend the same money on- more trains and better communication to inform subway riders on when the next train will arrive or that it will not arrive.

New York City drives the economy of New York State - and New York City is completely unworkable without the public transit system.  New York City should run state government - but instead, New York State politicians - most of whom have probably never been on a subway - control how the MTA is funded.  Small town upstate New York just can't understand how essential a great MTA is to the engine that fuels us all.  New York City will cease to function without affordable and dependable public transit - and the state will fail quickly after.  Let's find a way to make the MTA up-to-date and efficient.

Well for one thing - it costs nothing because the people who make the machines install them for "free" and sell advertising to pay for it...

As to why? It's the 21st century - people like using touch screens.

I have not bought a monthly MetroCard since Citibike came online, almost two years now.

I ride all year, even in the winter when it is 15 degrees, rain or snow, as soon as the streets are clear, which in NYC, is usually one day after a storm.

Anything, just anything, is better than riding on our subways.
Why corporate taxes? The fair way is to charge riders more.

Reading the comments makes me realize people forget we have to play catch up for all that went wrong in the 70's and 80's. It also makes me realize people have little idea how complicated it is to run such a huge system 24/7/365.

That said - the east river bridges need to be tolled and that money used to upgrade the signalling system in the subways ASAP!! It will add capacity by allowing more trains to run... AND it will cut "we are having delays due to signal trouble"... That will ease crowding and reduce delays on the subways.
Oh and please hurry up and replace Metro Card.

Gov Cuomo has a responsibility to help pay for the capital plan. Instead of proposing a wasteful air train to La Guardia (with no funding), pay for our existing system first! The proposed toll plan is a no brainer way to pay for it!

I might agree with you, except that the Tappan Zee is close to collapse and, if it were to close, where would those 138,000 vehicles go? Answer: most would redirect to the GWB which is already the most heavily trafficked bridge in the country and carries about 1,000,000 cars per day.
